discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
looks good to me

MITM is both Passive and Active but it depends on the situation. In this case the rest of the answers A. B. and D. is already interacting with the network so these actions are not passive at all. which leaves MITM. With MITM you're waiting and intercepting between two parties (e.g Sender/Victim and Server.) You sit in between no interaction at this point.
The answer is C

choices.C: Decompile the applications to approximate source code and then conduct a manual review.
choices.A: Launch the applications and use dynamic software analysis tools, including fuzz testing.
choices.B: Use a static code analyzer on the JAR files to look for code quality deficiencies.
choices.D: Review the details and extensions of the certificate used to digitally sign the code and the application.

discussion.content: C. this was on the exam

Selected Answer: C
looks good to me

The answer is 'A'
As described in CompTIA Pentest+ Pratice Test, Sybex.
Dynamic code analysis as well as fuzz testing are both performed on running
code. Because the source code is not required to perform these tests, they can be
performed during gray box or black box penetration tests.

I prefer to stick with A for this one, engineers can perform debugging to see those value changes. I did initially think C, but when it comes to detail analysis ill go with A and use tools like ollydbg for the dynamic analysis.

questions.question_text: A systems security engineer is preparing to conduct a security assessment of some new applications. The applications were provided to the engineer as a set that contains only JAR files. Which of the following would be the MOST detailed method to gather information on the inner workings of these applications?

discussion.content:
You solve this issue with password salting. A salt randomizes each hash by adding random data that is unique to each user to their password hash, so even the same password has a unique hash. If someone tried to compare hashes in a rainbow table to those in a database, none of the hashes would match, even if the passwords were the same.
C

Selected Answer: C
looks good to me

what i have understood is comptia questions have got no perfect answers. like each question has more than 1 solution. it was better if there was option to explain the answer so examiner can understand us.
C. this was on the exam
Agree with C

Answer is C:
Salting passwords is a common method of preventing rainbow table attacks, along with other password attacks such as dictionary attacks. A salt is a set of random data such as two additional characters. Password salting adds these additional characters to a password before hashing it. These additional characters add complexity to the password, and also result in a different hash than the system would create using the original password. This causes password attacks that compare hashes to fail.
Agree with C, going back to Sec+ this should be familiar.

questions.question_text: Which of the following BEST protects against a rainbow table attack?

looks good to me
This question was on the exam, I put B as the answer
Who the hell is preparing this dumps.... B is the correct one as in the others there is an interaction with the target.

B

Key wording "Passively" so OSINT

I agree the answer to this question would be B, but BuiltWith and Netcraft are not on the list of tools in the rubric for PT0-001. I would hope CompTIA wouldn't throw random tools not mentioned in the actual test.
agree its B
B: BuiltWith shows which technology is used by the site.

choices.A: Run a spider scan in Burp Suite.
choices.C: Run a web scraper and pull the website's content.
choices.D: Use Nmap to fingerprint the website's technology.
choices.B: Use web aggregators such as BuiltWith and Netcraft
